docs.lead_paragraph: Not too long ago, medical laboratory companies were as sick as many of the patients whose blood and urine they tested. The business was rife with overbilling and fraud. Managed health care companies were restricting the number of tests patients could have and the fees paid for them. Virtually every medical laboratory company was losing money.

headline.main: A Positive Culture For Making Profits; Buoyed by Mergers, Medical Labs Await Era of Gene Testing

docs.abstract: Medical laboratory industry, which has consolidated, leaving two giants, Quest Diagnostics and Laboratory Corp of America Holdings, is awaiting era of gene testing; analysts say first medical payoffs from genomics will not be drugs but diagnostic tests; start-up companies like diaDexus and Exact Sciences, as well as established companies like Applied BioSystems, are developing molecular diagnostics, term for gene and protein testing; they hope that patent protection for genes will allow them to charge higher prices for their tests than in past; graph; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The governor and legislative leaders reached an agreement today to amend the so-called Son of Sam law to make it possible for crime victims to sue criminals not just for profits from book and movie deals but also for virtually any money they receive while in prison. ''Criminals who have or gain the ability to pay will now be held accountable to their victims and their families,'' Gov. George E. Pataki said.

headline.main: Accord on Giving Victims More Clout in Son of Sam Law

docs.abstract: New York's so-called Son of Sam law, which enables crime victims to sue criminals for profits from book and movie deals, is amended to extend to any money they receive while in prison; statute of limitations is extended to give victims 10 years to sue (M)
docs.snippet: The governor and legislative leaders reached an agreement today to amend the so-called Son of Sam law to make it possible for crime victims to sue criminals not just for profits from book and movie deals but also for virtually any money they receive...

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Miami yesterday partly dismissed lawsuits that challenged the managed care practices of six big health insurers but said he would allow plaintiffs to amend their cases. Judge Federico Moreno of United States District Court rejected a motion to dismiss a claim against Humana Inc. under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act. But he said the plaintiffs had failed to show that RICO claims against the other companies -- Aetna Inc., Cigna, United Healthcare, Foundation Health Services and the Prudential unit of Aetna -- should proceed.

headline.main: Judge Issues Mixed Rulings In Suits Against H.M.O.'s

docs.abstract: Judge Federico Moreno partly dismisses lawsuits that challenges managed care practices of Aetna Inc, Cigna, United Healthcare, Foundation Health Services and Prudential unit of Aetna, but will allow plaintiffs to amend their cases; rejects motion to dismiss claim against Humana Inc under Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act; companies face more than 50 lawsuits from patients and doctors accusing them of conspiring to deny care and of withholding information about how business criteria influenced medical decisions (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lucent Credit Rating Is Cut To Junk Status by S.& P. Standard & Poor's lowered the credit rating of Lucent Technologies to junk-bond status, a move that could make it more costly for the company to borrow money. While the downgrade was expected, analysts said it could be more than a symbolic blow. Some investors voluntarily avoid buying securities issued by a company that is not considered investment grade; others are forbidden to do so by their own rules. [Page C4.]

docs.lead_paragraph: In a blow to President Bush, a key House Republican has decided to support patients' rights legislation that Senate Democrats are bringing forth as their first signature bill since they took control of the Senate. The Republican, Representative Charlie Norwood, a Georgia dentist, plans to make his announcement on Wednesday, just a day before a group of senators will meet at the White House to hammer out a compromise on legislation to regulate managed health care and define patients' rights.

headline.main: G.O.P. Congressman Will Support Democrats' Patients' Rights Bill

docs.abstract: Repr Charlie Norwood, Georgia dentist and key House Republican, deals blow to Pres Bush in announcing he will support patients' rights legislation to be brought forth by Democrats (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the first court ruling on the issue of gender equity in drug coverage, a federal judge in Seattle said yesterday that the Bartell Drug Company, a family-owned drugstore chain, discriminated against women when it excluded prescription contraceptives from its employee health plan. The class-action lawsuit, filed last July by Jennifer Erickson, a 27-year- old pharmacist at Bartell, said the health insurance coverage violated the Pregnancy Discrimination Act by paying for all the basic health care needs of male employees while leaving female employees to pay for contraception.

headline.main: Judge Says Some Employers Must Cover Contraceptives

docs.abstract: Federal Judge Robert S Lasnik rules in Seattle that Bartell Drug Company, family-owned chain, discriminated against women in exclusing prescription contraceptives from employee health benefit plan; class-action lawsuit filed by pharmacist Jennifer Erickson charged violations of Pregnancy Discrimination Act by paying for all basic health needs of male employees while leaving women to pay for contraception; she and Planned Parenthood lawyer Roberta Riley welcome summary ruling; photo; company adds coverage (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Devices and Desires: A History of Contraceptives in America,'' by Andrea Tone, Hill and Wang, $30. In 1992, Dr. Andrea Tone was finishing her dissertation at Emory University in Atlanta and volunteering at the Feminist Women's Health Center. While her academic labors focused on the history of industry, her work at the clinic provided an entirely different kind of food for thought, and eventually for research.

headline.main: Birth Control, From 'Womb Veils' to Lysol

docs.lead_paragraph: The LTV Corporation, a large steel maker, asked a bankruptcy court yesterday to terminate labor agreements and eliminate some retiree health benefits, and said it would cut about 800 jobs so it could avoid closing operations. The company, based in Cleveland, filed the motion with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Youngstown, Ohio. The changes are needed to save 7,700 jobs in the steel operations, LTV said. It said it had not made money in the last three years because it cannot compete against lower-priced imported steel and minimills.

headline.main: LTV ASKS COURT TO ELIMINATE SOME RETIREE BENEFITS

docs.lead_paragraph: Giants running back Joe Montgomery, whose career both as a collegian and as a professional has been beset by injury, ruptured his left Achilles' tendon yesterday and will miss the 2001 season. Montgomery, the team's 1999 second-round draft pick who turned 25 last week, was participating in the team's voluntary passing camp on the grass practice field adjacent to Giants Stadium. He changed direction during a routine pass route when the tendon snapped, the Giants said.
